awd_titl_txt: Bound State Theory and High Precision QED: Muonium, Positronium, Hydrogen, and Pentaquarks
awd_abstract_narration:
An area of active fundamental research in physics is the study of the hydrogen-like atoms and exotic atoms, atoms where one particle such as an electron is replaced by another such as a muon. Theoretical research of the properties of these systems represents the main goal of this project. In recent years, experiments in this area have reached an unprecedented level of accuracy, challenging the theory at a stronger and stronger level. Responding to this challenge, this project will provide theoretical input to the determination with higher precision of many fundamental physical constants, such as the electron-muon and electron-proton mass ratios, the proton charge radius, and the Rydberg constant. The new theoretical understanding developed here will be used in the next CODATA analysis of the fundamental physical constants. CODATA compilations of the fundamental constants are used in every science classroom, as well as in numerous fields of science and engineering, from fundamental research to consumer electronics. This project will also provide theoretical insight in the properties of pentaquarks, the bound states of five quarks recently discovered by the LHCb Collaboration at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN). Graduate and undergraduate students participating in this research will acquire research, computer, problem solving, and presentation skills. 

High precision quantum electrodynamics of hydrogen-like bound states is an active field of theoretical research motivated both by the spectacular experimental progress achieved in recent years and the intrinsic intellectual challenge. Despite significant progress in the theory of light hydrogen-like bound states, a number of challenging  problems remain and will be addressed in this research: 1) Complete calculation of all three-loop radiative-recoil corrections to hyperfine splitting in muonium, 2) Complete calculation of hard three-loop corrections to hyperfine splitting in positronium due to two-loop radiative insertions in the fermion lines in two-photon exchange nonannihilation diagrams, 3) Complete calculation of all relevant three-loop nonrecoil corrections to the Lamb shift in hydrogen and muonium. The above represent the largest unknown contributions to the Lamb shift in atomic physics. Respective three-loop nonrecoil corrections to hyperfine splitting in hydrogen and muonium will be calculated also. The PI will further develop the hadrocharmomium interpretation of pentaquarks. The project will provide quantitative description of their properties.

por.por_cntn:
Exotic pentaquarks with hidden charm were discovered not long ago by the LHCb collaboration at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. New experimental data on pentaquarks was reported in 2019 and later. Discovery of pentaquarks is a challenge for theory to explain  the nature of these bound states, describe their properties and predict new, yet undiscovered pentaquarks.   We addressed the theory of exotic pentaquarks in this research. Another topic of this research is  high precision quantum electrodynamics theory of  bound states, muonium, positronium and hydrogen.


 Earlier we suggested hadrocharmonium picture of pentaquarks inspired by quantum chromodynamics. In this scenario
one assumes that pentaquarks arise as a result of chromoelectric dipole interaction between a small quarkonium (charmonium) and a large baryon. Pentaquarks in the hadrocharmonium picture look like atomlike systems with a small nucleus whose role plays the quarkonium state and light nucleon quarks that play the role of the atomic electrons. The characteristic feature of this scenario is that the pentaquark decay into a charmonium state with hidden charm and an ordinary baryon is by far the dominant mode of decay. Decays into states with open charm are strongly suppressed because they can go only via exchange by a heavy open charm meson. In this research project we considered decays of the hidden charm LHCb pentaquarks in the  hadrocharmonium and molecular scenarios and obtained predictions for spin-parities and decay widths of the hidden charm pentaquarks in the hadrocharmonium and molecular pictures. In both pictures the LHCb pentaquarks are essentially nonrelativistic bound states. We developed a semirelativistic framework for calculation of the partial decay widths that allows the final particles to be relativistic and calculated the decay widths in the hadrocharmonium and molecular pictures. Molecular hidden charm pentaquarks are constructed as loosely bound states of charmed and anticharmed hadrons. Calculations show that molecular pentaquarks decay predominantly into states with open charm. Strong suppression of the molecular pentaquark decays into states with hidden charm is qualitatively explained by a relatively large size of the molecular pentaquark. The decay pattern of hadrocharmonium pentaquarks that are interpreted as loosely bound states of excited charmonium and nucleons is quite different. This time dominate decays into states with hidden charm. These results combined with the experimental data on partial decay widths could allow to figure out which of the two theoretical scenarios for pentaquarks (if either) is chosen by nature.
We predicted that in the hadrocharmonium scenario pentaquarks should be members of flavor multiplets which essentially repeat the pattern of low lying non exotic baryon multiplets. These multiplets should come in  almost degenerate hyperfine splitted pairs. One such pair of pentaquarks Pc(4440) and Pc(4457) was observed experimentally and the splitting turned out to be in accordance with our earlier theoretical prediction.  We predicted a series of hadrocharmonium states in the vicinity of the wide Pc(4380) pentaquark that can explain its apparently large decay width. Experimental measurements of  spin-parities of these states will allow to choose between the hadrocharmonium and molecular pentaquark models.

In the framework of this project we calculated ratios of partial decay widths of B- and Bs-mesons, which contain b quark, 
to eta and eta prime mesons. We described these decays using the methods developed earlier for solution of the U(1) problem.


In the framework of this project we addressed  existing in the literature discrepancy on the theoretical uncertainty of hyperfine splitting calculations in muonium. In the last twenty years, the theory of hyperfine splitting in muonium developed without any
experimental input. Finally, this situation is changing and a new experiment on measuring hyperfine
splitting in muonium is now in progress at J-PARC. This made resolution of theoretical discrepancies in the theory of muonium hyperfine splitting an absolute necessity. We addressed this problem and obtained  an unambiguous estimate of the theoretical uncertainty in the muonium hyperfine splitting

A new generation of 1S − 2S measurements in muonium and positronium is currently planned. This requires new high precision calculations of different contributions to the muonium and positronium  energy levels. We calculated a few series of hard spin-independent three-loop radiative corrections to energy levels in muonium and positronium which are due to radiative insertions in two-photon exchange diagrams.

New results obtained in this project contribute to the development of the theory of bound states in quantum chromodynamics and quantum electrodynamics. They are also either already found or will find in the future applications in discussion of the results of current and planned experiments at LHC, J-PARC  and other installations.
